articles.headline: Turning to a Turnaround Pro
articles.snippet: Frederick A. Henderson is charged with accelerating General Motors’s growth around the world while steering its comeback effort at home.
articles.abstract: Frederick A. Henderson is charged with accelerating General Motors’s growth around the world while steering its comeback effort at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  If General Motors were to design a president and chief operating officer from scratch, the new model would probably look a lot like Frederick A. Henderson.

articles.headline: Harvard’s $34.9 Billion Endowment Makes Its Choice for New Chief
articles.snippet: The Harvard Management Company appointed Jane Mendillo, the chief investment officer at Wellesley College, as its president and chief executive on Thursday.
articles.abstract: The Harvard Management Company appointed Jane Mendillo, the chief investment officer at Wellesley College, as its president and chief executive on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Harvard Management Company, which oversees the university’s $34.9 billion endowment, appointed Jane Mendillo, the chief investment officer at Wellesley College, as its president and chief executive on Thursday.

articles.headline: Palestinians Fear Two-Tier Road System
articles.snippet: An Israeli court’s acceptance of separate roads for Palestinians has brought accusations that it is the beginning of legal apartheid in the West Bank.
articles.abstract: An Israeli court’s acceptance of separate roads for Palestinians has brought accusations that it is the beginning of legal apartheid in the West Bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIT SIRA, West Bank  Ali Abu Safia, mayor of this Palestinian village, steers his car up one potholed road, then another, finding each exit blocked by huge concrete chunks placed there by the Israeli Army. On a sleek highway 100 yards away, Israeli cars whiz by.

articles.headline: For Americans, a Bit of the Swagger Is Gone
articles.snippet: Losses of confidence in America’s economy have occurred before, but renewal can take time when fear is self-fulfilling as businesses and consumers cut back.
articles.abstract: Losses of confidence in America’s economy have occurred before, but renewal can take time when fear is self-fulfilling as businesses and consumers cut back.
articles.lead_paragraph: America’s self-confidence is on the wane.

articles.headline: Clinton Details Premium Cap in Health Plan
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton said she would like to limit the cost of health insurance to no more than 10 percent of Americans’ income, a significant reduction for some families.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton said she would like to limit the cost of health insurance to no more than 10 percent of Americans’ income, a significant reduction for some families.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said in an interview on Wednesday that if elected president she would push for a universal health care plan that would limit what Americans pay for health insurance to no more than 10 percent of their income, a significant reduction for some families.

articles.headline: Odd Crop Prices Defy Economics
articles.snippet: Economists note there should not be two prices for one thing at the same place and time. But, in effect, that has been happening in trading that sets prices for corn, soybeans and wheat.
articles.abstract: Economists note there should not be two prices for one thing at the same place and time. But, in effect, that has been happening in trading that sets prices for corn, soybeans and wheat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Economists note there should not be two prices for one thing at the same place and time. Could a drugstore sell two identical tubes of toothpaste, and charge 50 cents more for one of them? Of course not.

articles.headline: Down $900 Million or More, the Chairman of Bear Sells
articles.snippet: The chairman of Bear Stearns, James E. Cayne, sold $61.3 million of the company’s shares, according to a regulatory filing.
articles.abstract: The chairman of Bear Stearns, James E. Cayne, sold $61.3 million of the company’s shares, according to a regulatory filing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only a year ago James E. Cayne’s stake in Bear Stearns was worth more than $1 billion. But on Thursday, Mr. Cayne, the chairman of Bear, disclosed that he had sold all of his shares in the troubled investment bank this week for just $61 million.

articles.headline: Assault by Iraq on Shiite Forces Stalls in Basra
articles.snippet: Iraqi security forces failed for a third straight day to oust Shiite militias.
articles.abstract: Iraqi security forces failed for a third straight day to oust Shiite militias.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  American-trained Iraqi security forces failed for a third straight day to oust Shiite militias from the southern city of Basra on Thursday, even as President Bush hailed the operation as a sign of the growing strength of Iraq’s federal government.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Parties Differ on Whom Economic Aid Should Help
articles.snippet: The presidential candidates’ ideological clashes are less about whether the government should step in and more about whom it should try to rescue.
articles.abstract: The presidential candidates’ ideological clashes are less about whether the government should step in and more about whom it should try to rescue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When an election campaign coincides with both a crisis on Wall Street and soaring home foreclosures across the country, the traditional ideological battles over “more government” or “less government” become blurred.
